speaker: Mr Baird
theText: to move:Thursday, 5 April 2001 MAIN COMMITTEE 26629 Thursday, 5 April 2001 ----Transport: National Strategy me that we do not have a national transport strategy in Australia and that our transport needs are approached very much on an ad hoc basis. This is not helped by the federal system in Australia. Each state seems to have its own priorities, and nothing emphasises this more than the different rail gauges that existed in the early days. It has taken years of effort and millions of dollars to get a somewhat uniform approach to rail, and the jealousies of the states in the early days have cost producers in this country millions of dollars. I am not one of those who argue for a road/rail approach-an either/or process. We need an integrated approach encompassing both road and rail, and implicit in this is that rail must receive proper funding and not be expected to compete against roads, as it were, with one hand tied behind its back. Some years ago the federal government accepted responsibility for some funding under the national highway program, but unless you are on that highway you are disadvantaged in regard to road. The Princes Highway linking Sydney to Melbourne along the South Coast should be declared a road of national importance. Just yesterday, the Prime Minister put a stop to that by saying that such a road would not receive federal funding, so deaths will continue on that road. Local producers will be disadvantaged, while the South Coast and Illawarra again miss out. You will appreciate, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, because of your campaign regarding North Coast roads, that there are more deaths per kilometre on the Princes Highway than there are on the Hume Highway. So there is absolutely no doubt that good roads save lives. Another part of my integrated plan is to have ports linked to the hinterland. ThusI have argued for many years for a replacement road to Macquarie Pass so that the port of Kembla can reach its full potential as an export development port to complement the work that the Port Kembla Corporation has achieved. I call on the Prime Minister and, indeed, the Deputy Prime Minister with his special responsibilities, to adequately fund the Princes Highway and to declare it a road of national importance. The whole Princes Highway network should be a road of national importance. It is good enough for the Sydney to Brisbane route to have two major roads and a railway. On the South Coast, the railway stops at Bomaderry. The only thing we have south of Bomaderry is a narrow deathtrap of a road. It should be adequately funded, because there is no other transport network there. The rail stops at Bomaderry and then you go onto the Princes Highway. I was on the Princes Highway last weekend. It is a narrow, dangerous deathtrap of a road. The statistics show that there are more deaths per kilometre on the Princes Highway than on the Hume Highway. speaker: Mr Slipper (Fisher
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Admini26630 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 5 April 2001 urging me to support more funding for the ATC in the 2001-02 budget. The Sunshine Coast’s growing tourism industry is becoming more and more dependent on an emerging demand for tourism income from abroad. That is why this issue is of great concern to me and to the thousands of Sunshine Coast residents who rely directly upon the success of the local tourism industry as their primary source of income. Inbound tourism is a major source of export earnings for this country. This year, the industry will generate $15.4 billion in export earnings. This industry represents big dollars for our economy. In light of Tourism Sunshine Coast’s support, coupled with intensive lobbying by the Australian Tourist Commission itself, I have chosen to write to the Prime Minister, the Treasurer, and the Minister for Sport and Tourism seeking favourable consideration of the ATC’s request for increased funding in the forthcoming budget. I have not taken that decision lightly, but the tourism industry on the Sunshine Coast is too valuable to the local economy for me not to act upon the concerns of tourism bodies and the community at large. It must be said that, during their 13 years in office, Labor’s attention to the Sunshine Coast and to Australian tourism industries was, to say the least, abysmal. Under Labor, tourism failed to meet its full potential and was undermined by red tape and poor economic management. Clearly, this government, unlike an ex union-organiser dominated Labor Party, contains many members who have a direct understanding-many from experience-of the issues that small business in the tourism industry face on a daily basis. The issue of the Australian Tourist Commission requiring greater funding is of considerable concern to me. They hope that by going public other parents may avoid the same plight. The West Australian also reports that in 1999 150 Australian children were involved in abductions, either into or from Australia. I believe we need to do more to address this international dilemma, particularly when we are dealing with children who are Australian citizens and who have been detained overseas against the wishes of a parent. Whilst the grandparents should have access to their grandchildren, the parent should always have precedence. In this case, the father is not in Malaysia-I am informed that he is in Hong Kong-and therefore he is not involved in their upbringing. I also call on the Malaysian government to help prevent the spread of this practice and to facilitate the early return of these children. speaker: Mr Emerson (Rankin) (10.00 A.m.)
theText: Yesterday I spoke in parliament about the impact26632 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 5 April 2001 because quite a lot of this industry’s costs are costs of imported items. With the dollar now below US50c, obviously the cost of imported material, such as paint, is now much greater as a result of the depreciation in the dollar. We were told before the GST was introduced that it would increase the value of the dollar. It has done nothing of the sort; the dollar, as we know, is now at an all-time low. In addition to that squeeze as a result of changes to the tax system, there is a squeeze on these small reputable operators within the smash repair industry by insurers themselves. They are forcing the small businesses to absorb the cost increases associated with the falling value of the dollar and also to absorb part of the GST. This is a very similar pattern of behaviour to that of the trucking companies which are squeezing drivers who are under pressure because of the GST and fuel cost increases. Insurers are also directing, in some cases, smash repairers to use non-genuine replacement parts, often without the knowledge of the owners of the vehicles. I call on the insurers to review their behaviour and their abuse of market power over these small and reputable smash repairers. We do not want the fly-by-night operators surviving and the reputable smash repairers going to the wall. The public needs to know what is going on-that is, a deteriorating quality of work, the use of non-genuine replacement parts and ethical operators being squeezed out by unethical behaviour. I link all of these realities to bankruptcy figures that were released just yesterday. In my home state of Queensland, bankruptcies are up to 21½ per cent in the three months to March compared with three months in the previous year. In addition, debt agreements are up by a massive almost 50 per cent. It was forecast by economic modellers that Queensland and Tasmania would be the states most adversely affected by the GST. Those forecasts are now becoming reality. It is not as if the government was not warned: even its own modellers predicted that Queensland and Tasmania would be the most adversely affected states. In Tasmania there was a massive 17.24 per cent increase in bankruptcies in the March quarter compared with the corresponding period for the previous year. Compare that with the Australia wide figure of 13.64 per cent. These are unacceptable figures. They are very high and, unfortunately, they are just as were predicted by economic modellers in the Australian Labor Party. But in today’s political climate the words ‘listening’ and ‘acting’ have significant importance. Following the results in the Western Australian and Queensland elections and the Ryan by-election, the Prime Minister has said that he is listening. We have seen the government backflips on beer, petrol, BAS and Australia Post. All politicians and all political parties are now passionate listeners. To be fair, even prior to these election setbacks, the government has been influenced by public protests over airport proposals at Kurnell and Holsworthy and, indeed, by an earlier airport protest meeting in Western Sydney at Jamieson Park. Most definitely, one of the reasons that the government have not moved to build an airport at Badgerys Creek is to protect their Western Sydney seats. I will give a few reasons why I believe an airport at Badgerys Creek is not acceptable to the general public. One clear indication was that the New South Wales Labor government went into the 1999 state election on an anti Badgerys Creek policy and won in a landslide. The New South Wales government, in its submission to the Commonwealth Minister for the Environment and Heritage concerning the environmental assessment for the proposed second Sydney Airport, stated: The NSW Government is opposed to the development of an airport at Badgerys Creek and favours an airport outside the Sydney basin. The Government is particularly concerned about the impact on the health, environment and quality of life of Western Sydney residents. Furthermore, the Commonwealth continues to ignore the critical issue of funding for off-site infrastructure such as road and rail construction, required to provide for an airport at Badgerys Creek. The EIS fails to assess the likely environmental impacts of the required off-site infrastructure and has underestimated the cost of this infrastructure by about $3 billion. In an independent report titled Sydney Gateways in the 21st Century, prepared by Access Economics, it was stated that a second Sydney airport would eventually be necessary to serve the long-term growth in passenger demand. But passenger demand for Badgerys Creek would only become sufficient to generate positive economic benefits by the year 2020. By this time the population of Western Sydney would be greater than the rest of Sydney combined. Commencing operations prior to 2020 would, according to the report by Access Economics, result in negative economic benefits and require massive taxpayer funded subsidies. Coupled with this local assessment of the economic benefits, or lack thereof, of an airport at Badgerys Creek is the international experience of the operation of second airports in general. The 1985 site selection program gives some very interesting information regarding second airports. Second airports do not take on the role of the primary airport in a city. De Gaulle Airport in Paris is the busiest second airport compared to its dominant partner, with 84 aircraft movements for every 100 at Orly Airport. The site selection program goes on to state: This situation of traffic concentration at primary airports exists despite repeated efforts by many governments to distribute traffic more evenly. It goes on to state: In Washington for example it was expected that 50% of all passengers for the city would pass through the new Washington-Dulles international terminal by 1967, five years after its opening. However more than twenty years after its opening it has 10% of the total traffic. Australian Labor Party: Industrial Relations Policy Computer magazine, much was made of the TLA syndrome affecting the world-the threeletter acronym-and how it sums up some of the worries and frustrations of the general community around the world. Of course, just last night, the Australian Labor Party, the ALP, invoked their hideous threeletter acronym approach yet again upon the small business sector in my community by voting down the secondary boycott provisions within changes to the Trade Practices Act. Tasmania: Regional Medical Services has made the recruitment of doctors in country Tasmania almost impossible. It is hard enough to get doctors to come and practise in Tasmania-yet this government is determined that those who are in the country are unable to get help. In my electorate I have two centres that have recently been reclassified from rural RRMA5 areas for medical provision to urban RRMA1 areas. One is Sorell, covering the south and east coast of Tasmania, and the other is New Norfolk, servicing the Derwent Valley. Apparently these towns are different from Devonportwhich retains its rural classification despite being a bigger town and being within a 10-minute drive of a hospital-and Huonville, which is a similar drive time away from Hobart. This is patently ridiculous. The nearest hospital to these centres is a good 45-minute drive away from both these towns and, unless you break the speed limit, the impact that this reclassification has on medical services has become critical. Doctors in these areas do not just service the townspeople. Both areas stretch out into the rural areas around them and provide a service all over the regions. It is becoming more and more difficult for those doctors to do their jobs, let alone try to cope with new patients. The New Norfolk situation is particularly serious, because one doctor has retired and two others are in their 70s. There are also two doctors who are overseas trained, and the one local who has remained has been run ragged and is almost at the end of his tether as he has lost his two OTDs and, if something is not done soon to help him gain some assistance, he is likely to throw in the sponge. This is another move to get rid of country services. The viability of the hospital, X-ray services, Corumbene, residential units housing ex-Willow Court residents, and Millbrook Rise is dependent on the availability of medical personnel. If doctors cannot work because of the barriers, these services could close. Australian trained doctors are given no incentive to be country doctors, so why would they put themselves into a situation of being overworked, with no time off and very little hope of getting assistance if they have to leave the practice for a short time? Therefore, many doctors still struggling to stay in their communities have opted to attract overseas trained doctors because they are allowed to work only in rural areas. Changing New Norfolk and Sorell to ‘metropolitan’ means that no-one will be prepared to take on such a practice. New Norfolk has now lost four full-time GPs, two as a result of direct federal government intervention. With the current barriers that are in place, there is no chance of these GPs being replaced. I have asked the minister twice for a solution, but I am only getting platitudes. Why was this system changed? Why isn’t the minister prepared to front the issue head-on and give us some proper answers? Main Committee adjourned at 10.30 a.m.

theText: I wish to point out to the House that this governmentThe following answers to questions were circulated: Canberra Electorate: Nursing Home Spot Checks (Question No. 2072) Ms Ellis asked the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 12 October 2000: (1) Between March 1996 and August 2000, how many spot checks were carried out on nursing homes within the electoral division of Canberra. (2) How many complaints regarding nursing homes within the electoral division of Canberra were received by her in (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999 and (e) 2000. (3) Will spot checks be undertaken by her Department after a nursing home receives accreditation; if so, will they be done on a yearly, half-yearly, quarterly, monthly or random basis. Mrs Bronwyn Bishop-The answer to the honourable member’s question, in accordance with advice provided to me, is as follows: (1) Four spot checks were carried out by the Department on residential aged care facilities in the electoral division of Canberra between March 1996 and March 2001. (2) This information is protected under the Aged Care Act 1997. (3) Yes. Spot checks will be undertaken by the Department on a random basis. Family Court: Counselling Services (Question No. 2107) Ms Livermore asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 November 2000: (1) With respect to the recent and anticipated reduction of counselling services operated by the Family Court, how will counselling services which are, or until recently were, provided by the Family Court, be provided in future. (2) How does the Court propose to meet the needs of clients for whom they will no longer be able to offer these services. (3) What role will the community-based not-for-profit organisations, funded to provide counselling services under the Family Law Act, be expected to play in picking up those clients who would have been seen by Court personnel. (4) Where there is more than one community-based not-for-profit organisation which provides such services in a location in which services were previously provided by the Family Court, how will a decision be taken as to which organisation should provide those services. (5) Will these organisations be expected to increase their service levels from within their existing resources. (6) Will the Court be contracting out mediation or counselling services previously delivered by the Court, and what is the process by which such contracts have been, or will be, awarded. (1) The Family Court of Australia (the Court) advises that, over the last two years, it has adopted a strategy of reducing its pre-filing counselling services in line with the development of community based counselling organisations that are able to offer a range of services to clients. The Court continues to work with my Department, the Department of Family and Community Services, community-based not for profit organisations as well as referrers to ensure that clients seeking this service are offered a range of options. The Court is also concerned, particularly in regional areas, to retain a capacity to provide pre-filing counselling. (2) The Court advises that it has for a considerable period been working with community-based, not for profit organisations on joint strategies that would assist appropriate pre-filing clients to access their services. (3) Through the Family Relationships Services Program (FRSP), community-based organisations are funded to provide counselling and mediation services under the Family Law Act. However, it is
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:anticipated that the role of some organisations will expand over time to meet the needs of clients of the Federal Magistrates Service as well as those of the Court. The Court has developed links with the FRSP service providers for client referral where they are able to provide similar services. In metropolitan areas, there are a greater number of community agencies to meet the demand for services. While there will be some capacity in the agencies to absorb additional work generated by the Court referrals, the different counselling and mediation model used by the Court will require different skills. I have recently approved the use of $1.75 million from 1999-00 Budget funds for community organisations in the metropolitan areas where Family Court voluntary counselling services will not be available. This amount will ensure that the community organisations are appropriately equipped to deal with the work formerly undertaken by the Court. My Department, the Family Court, the Department of Family and Community Services and industry representative bodies are working together to ensure a smooth transition of the skills and services from the Court to the community based organisations. (4) In the case of the metropolitan registries serviced by the Court, the Court advises that this issue is being considered in the development of the transition strategy. In all other areas, the Court offers pre-filing counselling clients a choice between the appropriate community organisations available in their location. This is done in consultation with the organisations concerned. (5) Community-based organisations are expected to be flexible in addressing their community’s needs. However, the growing demand for counselling has been recognised by the Government and counselling organisations funded under the FRSP have already received an additional, proportional increase in funds. In the 1999-00 Budget additional funds of $15.7 million over three years were announced for the expansion of primary dispute resolution services. In the 2000-01 financial year, funding will be available for targeted areas where a high need for primary dispute resolution is identified. These measures will result in greater availability of dispute resolution services from community-based organisations. (6) The Court advises that it will continue to provide court ordered counselling and family reports in all its locations. In the Rockhampton area there is a pilot being considered for court ordered counselling, in appropriate cases, to be provided by a number of community-based, not-for-profit organisations. It is proposed that a panel would be established in consultation with the organisations themselves and the local community. This pilot is in response to difficulties the Court has experienced in recruiting and retaining counselling staff in this location. There has been, however, no decision made to proceed with the pilot at this time. Aged Care Facilities: 75 Thames Street Hostel (Question No. 2192) Ms Burke asked the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 29 November 2000: (1) How many complaints to her Department has she received about the 75 Thames Street Hostel since it opened. (2) On what dates were these complaints made and when were they acted upon by her Department. Mrs Bronwyn Bishop-The answer to the honourable member's question, in accordance with advice provided to me, is as follows: (1) Nine. (2) These complaints have all been finalised. Nursing Homes: Budget (Question No. 2217) Dr Theophanous asked the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 5 December 2000: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1803 (Hansard, 28 November 2000), is she stating that both she and her Department have no data regarding both ethnic-specific and multi-ethnic nursing homes and hostels. (2) If this is the case, how can she allocate the proportion of the Aged Care Budget for people from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds in a fair manner which ensures that all communities are provided an equitable level of funding. (3) If this is not the case, can she supply the information as requested in question No. 1803. Mrs Bronwyn Bishop-The answer to the honourable member's question, in accordance with advice provided to me, is as follows: (1) The Department does not have specific data on ethno-specific and multi-ethnic facilities dating back to 1990. (2) and (3) The Department monitors access to residential aged care by using statistics on the proportion of residents from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds in residential aged care facilities compared to the proportion in the population aged 70 and over in Aged Care Planning Regions. Aged Care Facilities: Allandale (Question No. 2224) Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 6 December 2000: (1) How many beds at the Allandale Aged Care Facility in Cessnock are licensed to accommodate people with (a) high; and (b) low care needs. (2) What sum of Commonwealth funding did the Allandale Aged Care Facility receive in 1999-2000 for (a) high care; (b) low care; and (c) group home residents. (3) Is the Hunter Area Health Service receiving the maximum possible sum of Commonwealth funding for each of the 336 high-care beds at Allandale; if not, why not. (4) Has she or her department held discussions with the Hunter Area Health Service regarding proposals to sell the Allandale facility to the not-for-profit sector. (5) Have the Hunter Area Health Service and her Department agreed to reduce the number of highcare beds at Allandale by 120; if so, to where will the high-care beds go. (6) What mix of high care, low care and hostel beds has the Commonwealth agreed to fund under the Hunter Area Health Service’s proposal to sell Allandale. (7) How much more funding will a not-for-profit provider receive from the Commonwealth over a financial year period than the Hunter Area Health Service receives currently. (8) Has the Commonwealth imposed any condition upon the Hunter Area Health Service which leaves it with no choice but to sell the Allandale Facility. (9) Is the proposed sale likely to lead to a reduction in employment levels at Allandale. (10) Has Allandale now achieved full Commonwealth accreditation; if so, was there any delay in awarding accreditation or were any particular care-standard problems identified throughout the assessment process. Mrs Bronwyn Bishop-The answer to the honourable member's question, in accordance with advice provided to me, is as follows: (1) The approved number of places at Allandale Aged Care Facility is 336 high care places. (2) Total funding for 1999/2000 was $10,551,857.91. (3) Payments of Commonwealth subsidy are based on the assessed support needs (Residential Care Subsidy or “RCS” levels) of residents plus any eligible supplements, as set out by the service provider in monthly payments claim forms sent to the Department. (4) The Department has attended discussions with the Hunter Area Health Service regarding their proposal to sell the Allandale facility to a non-government provider. No sale or transfer of aged care places may occur without the approval of the Secretary of the Department. (5) I am advised that the Hunter Area Service applied in the 2000 Aged Care Approvals Round for restructuring assistance and the Department has allocated 35 residential low care places for the Allandale facility. Other questions should be referred to the Hunter Area Health Service. (6) and (7)I am advised that the Department has not approved any proposal to transfer places from the Allandale facility. (8) No (9) This question should be referred to the Hunter Area Health Service. (10) Allandale has been awarded the maximum three years accreditation. Aged Care Facilities: Fees (Question No. 2290) Mr O’Keefe asked the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 6 February 2001: (1) What is the maximum percentage of Age Pension which can be classified as essential expenditure for the purpose of assessing fees payable in aged care facilities. (2) Does the Government encourage aged care residents to maintain private health insurance cover. (3) Are private health insurance fees regarded as essential expenditure for the purpose of calculating essential expenditure; if not, why not. Mrs Bronwyn Bishop-The answer to the honourable member’s question, in accordance with advice provided to me, is as follows: (1) Fees payable in aged care facilities are determined in accordance with the provisions contained in the Aged Care Act 1997. (2) The decision to take out private health insurance is a personal choice. The Lifetime Health Cover that was introduced in July 2000 includes a special provision for older people. People born on or before 1 July 1934 are not affected by Lifetime Health Cover. They are able to take out hospital cover with a registered health fund at any time in the future and pay a premium with no additional loading for late entry. (3) Private health insurance is generally regarded as a discretionary expense for the purpose of financial hardship assistance as Medicare provides medical services, medicines and acute health care for all Australians. The Commonwealth also provides a range of assistance to assist elderly Australians with their medical costs. These include: funding the residential aged care sector to provide a range of services to residents for no additional charge. These include items such as physiotherapy and podiatry for high care residents that are normally covered by private health insurance. As care recipients already receive these services at no additional charge, many choose not to take out private health insurance; the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and Health Care Card that ensure pensioners receive subsidised health items and pharmaceuticals; and for those care recipients who pay tax, the Medical Expenses Rebate is available where medical expenses, including residential aged care costs, are above $1250 per year. Education: Loans Scheme (Question No. 2336) Mr Latham asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on Wednesday, 7 February 2001: Further to the Government’s announcement of a loans scheme for postgraduate courses, (a) will the scheme include scope for an upfront payment with a discount, (b) will the loans be repaid concurrently with HECS repayments and (c) what measures will the Government introduce to ensure that such a scheme does not lead to universities increasing the level of postgraduate fees. (a) Up-front payment arrangements are the responsibility of the individual higher education institution. (b) Yes. (c) It is expected that increased competition for a growing postgraduate coursework market and close community attention to universities’ pricing policies will keep prices within acceptable limits. I

speaker: Dr Kemp
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:have asked my Department to monitor the prices charged for postgraduate courses and to report on these annually through the higher education reports. There will not be a cap on the amount each student may borrow each semester. However, I propose to include in the Bill to establish the Scheme provision for the Minister to have discretion to determine a cap on the total level of students’ borrowings. I propose to exercise that authority only if experience indicates a need for a prudent financial limit on student borrowings or for a mechanism to dampen prices being charged. Regional Forest Agreements: Reports (Question No. 2341) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on February 2001: (1) In respect of each signed Regional Forest Agreement (RFA), (a) How many annual progress reports have been received to date by the Commonwealth, and (b) What was the date on which each report was received. (2) In respect of each RFA for which an annual progress report has to date not been received, when does the Commonwealth expect to receive the first annual report from the relevant State Government. (1)(a) Five RFA Regional Forest Agreement (RFA) annual reports have been completed to date, two of which cover more than one RFA region. As all the RFA milestones contain joint commitments, most RFA annual reports finalised to date have been developed jointly by the Commonwealth and the states. The exception is the Tasmanian RFA, for which separate Commonwealth and state reports were developed for 1998 and 1999. A report for 2000 has also been received from Tasmania. For Victoria, joint Commonwealth-state RFA annual reports have been developed for the East Gippsland and the Central Highlands RFAs (combined report for 1998), and the East Gippsland, Central Highlands and North East Victoria RFAs (combined report for 1999). (1)(b) RFA annual reports covering Tasmanian state-only commitments were received in December 1998, December 1999 and February 2001. All other RFA annual reports to date have been developed jointly by the Commonwealth and the states through an iterative process. The 1998 Victorian RFA annual report (covering East Gippsland and the Central Highlands) was agreed between Commonwealth and state officials in April 1999. The 1999 Victorian RFA report (covering East Gippsland, Central Highlands and North East Victoria) was agreed between officials in October 2000. The 1999 Tasmanian and Victorian RFA annual reports were tabled in May 2000 and February 2001 respectively. The 1998 Victorian RFA annual reports, and the 1998 and 2000 Tasmanian reports will be tabled in the near future. (2) First RFA annual reports are due for the Western Australian, Eden, North East NSW, West Victoria and Gippsland RFAs. To avoid duplication of effort, RFA annual reports have been combined and/or compiled simultaneously with other state reporting requirements. In some instances, this will result in the first RFA reports being delayed. For the Eden and North East NSW RFAs, the reports are now scheduled for completion in March 2001. Joint Commonwealth-state reports for 2000 are currently being finalised for the Western Australian RFA and all five Victorian RFAs (including first reports for the West Victoria and Gippsland RFAs). Veterans’ Affairs Portfolio: Procurement Policies (Question No. 2401) Mr Sidebottom asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, upon notice, on 1 March 2001: (1) Is the Minister’s Department, or are agencies within the portfolio, large purchasers or consumers of office papers.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Tuckey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) How are Commonwealth procurement guidelines being adhered to by the Minister’s Department and agencies within the portfolio. (3) What methodology or weighting criteria does the Minister’s Department and agencies use to determine the importance of the core principles which underpin the procurement guidelines, namely (a) value for money, (b) open and effective competition, (c) ethics and fair dealing, (d) accountability and reporting, (e) national competitiveness and industry development and (f) support for other Commonwealth policies. (4) What weighting criteria are used to implement the mandatory provisions in the guidelines which state that agencies must be able to demonstrate that Australia New Zealand (ANZ) suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete. (5) In inviting suppliers to tender for the provision of goods, are suppliers advised that they must offer ANZ goods. (6) If the Minister’s Department or agencies within the portfolio do not have weighting criteria for determining the principles, will the Minister take steps to ensure that they provide an appropriate means to demonstrate their compliance with Commonwealth procurement policy. Mr Bruce Scott-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) The Department of Veterans’ Affairs purchases about 60,000 reams of office paper each year. (2) In accordance with Commonwealth Procurement principles and guidelines, quotations for office paper are sought from suppliers as demand requires. (3) and (4) In assessing the offers from the paper suppliers, the Department takes into account price, conformity to specification, compatibility of the paper with its office machines, and suppliers’ ability to meet delivery requirements. Unsuccessful respondents are notified of the purchasing decision and purchases of $2,000 or more in value are publicly notified in the Gazette Publishing System. The Department ensures that in seeking supplies of office paper the specification does not exclude ANZ suppliers. The Department is seeking to include ANZ suppliers by having regard to the Industrial Supplies Office’s advice on which suppliers meet the requirement. (5) No. (6) In conducting its procurement activities the Department observes the relevant Commonwealth Procurement principles and guidelines. New South Wales Timber Industry: Funding (Question No. 2450) Mr Horne asked the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on 8 March 2001: (1) What sum has been provided by the Federal Government to the timber industry in NSW under the Forest Industry Structural Adjustment Package (FISAP) over the past five years. (2) Now that the Regional Forest Agreements have been signed by the Federal Government, will he give an assurance that FISAP money will start to flow immediately to the NSW timber industry for its vital reconstruction. (1) The Commonwealth has paid $18,445,618 to the timber industry in NSW since 1995/96 under the NSW FISAP. (2) The Southern Regional Forest Agreement (RFA) in NSW has not yet been finalised. It is my intention that FISAP in NSW will resume once the Southern RFA has been signed.
